item.title: Black & Brew, an East Passyunk Avenue mainstay, will lose its lease at the end of February
item.description: Black & Brew, the cafe on East Passyunk Avenue in South Philadelphia, must move to a new location after 17 years at its current storefront. The Passyunk Ave Revitalization Corp. is not offering the business the chance to renew its lease at 1523 E. Passyunk Ave., claiming Black & Brew has unpaid debt. Caf√© owner Colleen DeCesare says the business is committed to finding a new location.
item.dc:creator: Michael Tanenbaum

item.title: Norristown water main break leaves more than 300 properties without water
item.description: A water main break in Norristown early Monday morning caused flooding and street closures. The damaged pipe affected water service to about 300 properties. Some residents voluntarily evacuated their homes and repairs to the area are expected to take most of Monday, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Althouse

item.title: Philly updates its list of 'bad actor' employers, adding two new businesses in latest report
item.description: Philly's Office of Worker Protections added two local companies to its bad actors list for not resolving violations of labor laws: Making Life Easier and Angel Service of Philadelphia.
item.dc:creator: Kristin Hunt

item.title: Drexel plans new 'front lawn' to replace demolished dorms in University City
item.description: Drexel University plans to build a new campus green space at the site of the former Myers Hall, which is currently undergoing demolition near 33rd and Race streets in University City. The lawn will be mostly open space and planting beds, with a plaza that includes seating. The space also will be outfitted with electrical outlets. Drexel is targeting an opening in fall 2024.
item.dc:creator: Michael Tanenbaum

item.title: Northbound I-95 lanes in Center City to close for 36 hours in early February
item.description: The northbound lanes of I-95 will close between the Columbus Boulevard and I-676 exits from Saturday, Feb. 3 until early Monday, Feb. 5 so crews can continue work on a $329 million project to cap I-95 with an 11 1/2-acre park that will connect Old City with Penn's Landing.
item.dc:creator: John Paul Titlow

item.title: Cherry Hill completes purchase to preserve 23-acre Holly Ravine Farm
item.description: Cherry Hill has completed the $3.86 million purchase of Holly Ravine Farm, a 23-acre property that had been targeted by developers for a senior housing complex. The land will now be permanently preserved as an open space. The property previously was owned by the family of former Cherry Hill Mayor John Gilmour Jr. It was once home to the Cowtail Bar ice cream parlor and a petting zoo.
item.dc:creator: Michael Tanenbaum

item.title: Fight at Robeson High School high school put school on lockdown
item.description: A fight at Paul Robeson High School for Human Services caused an hour-long lockdown Monday. Several students have been suspended, and school officials said family members of students were involved in the fight. A cause for the altercation remains unclear.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Althouse

item.title: Surveillance video shows man accused of stabbing Temple University employee
item.description: Philadelphia police released security camera footage Monday that shows the man suspected of stabbing a Temple University employee last week at 10th Street and Montgomery Avenue. The video shows the man inside a store shortly after the assault. Police say he used the employee's credit card there.
item.dc:creator: Chris Compendio

item.title: Countdown clocks arrive at more stations along Market-Frankford Line
item.description: Countdown clocks appeared at SEPTA's 30th Street and Girard stations along the Market-Frankford Line. They show riders when the next train is scheduled to arrive. SEPTA said it's testing the devices with no firm date on an official rollout.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Althouse

item.title: Philly pharmacy will pay $4.6 million to resolve fraud investigations
item.description: A Philadelphia pharmacy will pay $4.6 million to resolve health care fraud investigations. Federal prosecutors say Pennmark Pharmacy on South Street billed Medicaid and Medicare for prescriptions that were never dispensed.
item.dc:creator: Kristin Hunt

item.title: Pearl Properties updates look of 35-story tower planned on Jewelers' Row
item.description: Pearl Properties has shared new renderings of the 35-story tower proposed for a vacant stretch of Jewelers' Row on Sansom Street, where multiple historic rowhomes were demolished for a Toll Brothers project that was never built. The new proposed building overlooks Washington Square and would have 99 units.
item.dc:creator: Michael Tanenbaum

item.title: Trial for killing of Temple police officer approaches; family wants the accused to receive death penalty
item.description: Miles Pfeffer, 19, is heading to trial for the February 2023 murder of Temple University police officer Christopher Fitzgerald. Fitzgerald's family has criticized the length of time the trial process has taken, also calling for Pfeffer to receive the death penalty.
item.dc:creator: Chris Compendio

item.title: Philly receives $25 million federal grant for flood prevention, drinking water projects
item.description: Drinking water improvements, flood prevention and a cleaner Delaware River are on the docket with a $25 million federal grant the Philadelphia Water Department received Wednesday. Funds, which come from President Biden's American Rescue Plan, will be put toward projects in Port Richmond, East Falls and Germantown.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Althouse

item.title: Rare, colorful painted bunting draws bird lovers to Bartram's Garden
item.description: At Bartram's Garden, a rare sighting of a colorful painted bunting has drawn bird lovers to the 50-acre public park in Southwest Philly. The species is native to the southeast U.S., Mexico, the Caribbean and Central America. When the males mature, they molt to reveal their vibrantly colored plumage that fuses bright shades of blue, green, yellow and red.
item.dc:creator: Michael Tanenbaum

item.title: ESA Letter: 3 ESA Letters That Make It So You and Your Pet Never Have To Be Apart
item.description: An emotional support animal letter, or an ESA letter, is a great way to ensure you receive the mental health accommodations your emotional support animal provides.
item.dc:creator: Originated Media

item.title: Police search for 17-year-old accused of murder who escaped custody outside CHOP
item.description: Philadelphia police are searching for escaped prisoner Shane Pryor, 17, who is accused of murder for allegedly killing a woman in 2020 . Pryor fled Wednesday after being transported to Children's Hospital of Philadelphia in University City, investigators said.
item.dc:creator: Michael Tanenbaum

item.title: U.S. House committee claims Penn enabled 'pervasive antisemitism' on campus
item.description: Rep. Virginia Foxx, of the U.S. House committee investigating antisemitism at the University of Pennsylvania, wrote a letter requesting documents relating to the Ivy League school's responses to antisemitic incidents on campus since 2021. The letter lists 25 items that the committee wants Penn to produce by Feb. 7.
item.dc:creator: Chris Compendio

item.title: Fire at Willow Grove auto-repair shop allegedly was set by ex-employee
item.description: Sean Gahagan, 56, of Lebanon, is charged with arson for allegedly starting two fires in Montgomery County on Dec. 29, 2023. Investigators say Gahagan set fire to a Willow Grove auto-repair shop where he once worked and another fire at a shed nearby in Huntingdon Valley.
item.dc:creator: Michael Tanenbaum

item.title: 76ers have gathered 30,000 signatures backing their Center City arena proposal
item.description: The Philadelphia 76ers say they have collected 30,000 signatures from people who support their proposed $1.55 billion arena in Center City. The results follow a survey that found Washington Square West residents overwhelmingly oppose the arena, and various opposition efforts from Chinatown residents.
item.dc:creator: Michael Tanenbaum

item.title: Video shows teen fugitive Shane Pryor in CHOP building moments after escape
item.description: Shane Pryor, the 17-year-old accused murderer who escaped custody in University City on Wednesday, was seen in video at a Children's Hospital of Philadelphia building minutes after he fled from authorities. Investigators believe Pryor left University City around 12:30 p.m. U.S. Marshals in Philadelphia are offering a $5,000 reward for information that leads to Pryor's capture.
item.dc:creator: Michael Tanenbaum

item.title: School District of Philadelphia will double its electric buses over the next 3 years
item.description: The School District of Philadelphia will double its electric buses over the next three years with a new grant from the Environmental Protection Agency. Officials expect to have 40 zero-emissions vehicles by 2027.
item.dc:creator: Kristin Hunt

item.title: City Council's majority leader wants to investigate the Office of Homeless Services
item.description: Philadelphia City Council's majority leader, Katherine Gilmore Richardson, is making inquiries into Philly's Office of Homeless Services. During the first in-person City Council session since the pandemic began, Gilmore Richardson introduced legislation that would begin an investigation and establish an ombudsperson.
item.dc:creator: Chris Compendio

item.title: Escaped prisoner Shane Pryor fled University City with help of another teen, police say
item.description: Michael Diggs, 18, has been charged for allegedly aiding the escape of inmate Shane Pryor outside Children's Hospital of Philadelphia on Wednesday afternoon. Diggs allegedly picked Pryor up after he fled from escort staff in the hospital's emergency parking lot. Pryor, who remains on the run, is charged with the 2020 killing of a woman who was fatally shot in the Holmesburg section of Northeast Philadelphia.
item.dc:creator: Michael Tanenbaum

item.title: Tony Luke's cheesesteak shop owners sentenced to prison for tax fraud
item.description: The owners of South Philly's original Tony Luke's cheesesteak shop have each been sentenced to serve 20 months in prison for their decade-long tax fraud scheme. Nicholas Lucidonio, 57, and Anthony Lucidonio Sr., 84, concealed millions of dollars in sales from the IRS between 2006-2016, federal prosecutors said. The future of the decades-old business is now in question.
item.dc:creator: Michael Tanenbaum

item.title: Northwest Philly residents petition Gov. Shapiro to 'save' SEPTA's Chestnut Hill West line
item.description: Northwest Philly residents who depend on the Chestnut Hill West line have signed a petition urging Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro to provide additional funding for SEPTA in the state budget. The transit authority may make substantial service cuts if it can't overcome a projected $240 operating budget deficit and residents fear the Chestnut Hill West line may be cut.
item.dc:creator: Chris Compendio

item.title: Man who allegedly abandoned infant at Northeast Philly Walmart faces multiple charges
item.description: Philadelphia police have charged 22-year-old Alganon Muhammad for allegedly abandoning a baby girl at Walmart last week when he and two other people were confronted for shoplifting at the store in Northeast Philadelphia. Muhammad is charged with endangering the welfare of a child, retail theft, criminal conspiracy and recklessly endangering another person. Police are still searching for the other two suspects.
item.dc:creator: Michael Tanenbaum

item.title: Police officer hospitalized after shootout at North Philly convenience store
item.description: A fatal shootout in a Fairhill convenience store left one officer shot and a suspect killed. The officer is receiving care at the Temple University Hospital, while police continue to search for a man who allegedly stole the suspect's gun at the scene after the shootout.
item.dc:creator: Chris Compendio

item.title: Meet Phantom, Adventure Aquarium's new giant Pacific octopus
item.description: Adventure Aquarium, located in Camden, recently welcomed a male giant Pacific octopus who is about 1 year old. Thanks to a public vote, the octopus has been named Phantom, after 'The Phantom of the Opera,' in honor of a scar across his eye. Visitors can see Phantom now on exhibit in Zone D.
item.dc:creator: Franki Rudnesky

item.title: Escaped prisoner Shane Pryor apprehended on SEPTA bus in North Philly, police say
item.description: Shane Pryor was arrested by a U.S. Marshals task force Sunday night in North Philadelphia ‚Äì four days after the accused murderer escaped from authorities at the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia. Pryor, 17, was apprehended on a SEPTA bus at Third Street and Roosevelt Boulevard, investigators said.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Althouse

item.title: Gov. Shapiro to propose $282.8 million in new funding for public transit in 2024-25 state budget
item.description: Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro plans to propose $282.8 million for public transit in his 2024-25 budget. The proposal would give SEPTA enough money to avoid immediate service cuts and fare increases. The plan would generate $1.5 billion over five years through a reallocation of sales tax revenue.
item.dc:creator: Kim Lyons, Pennsylvania Capital-Star

item.title: Pa. Game Commission tables plan to reintroduce American martens into ecosystem
item.description: The Pennsylvania Game Commission voted to table a plan to reintroduce American martens, a weasel species that was wiped out of the state by the early 20th century. The omnivorous mammal was extirpated due to the fur trade and deforestation, but some states have begun restoring their populations in recent decades. Although the general public supported the plan, a survey of hunters revealed conflicting views on the American marten's return. The plan will now undergo further research and consideration.
item.dc:creator: Michael Tanenbaum

item.title: State lawmakers want to create a rider advocacy commission for NJ Transit
item.description: A day after NJ Transit proposed a 15% fare hike, state lawmakers advanced a bill that would create a rider advocacy commission. The proposed customer advocate office would represent the interests of public transit riders in areas such as fare increases and service decreases. The office would also be able to conduct independent investigations and studies and provide comments and feedback directly to the agency and legislators.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Nieto-Munoz, New Jersey Monitor

item.title: Mechanical issue on SEPTA's Market-Frankford Line causes delays
item.description: A mechanical issue on the Market-Frankford Line late Monday night prompted SEPTA to run shuttle buses between the Spring Garden and Allegheny stops. SEPTA officials said the train did not derail, as earlier reports suggested. Delays were expected to continue Tuesday morning.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Althouse

item.title: Car crashes into Family Dollar in North Philly after colliding with tow truck
item.description: A car and a tow truck crashed at 22nd and Cambria streets in North Philadelphia early Tuesday morning, causing a fire that damaged a nearby Family Dollar grocery store. Police said the car ran a red light and struck the tow truck. The impact caused the car to knock over a light pole and traffic light before it crashed into the grocery store and caught fire.
item.dc:creator: Chris Compendio

item.title: Cybersecurity 101: Safeguarding Your Digital Life From Cyber Shadows
item.description: Cyber-attacks are a silent yet pervasive threat in the 4th and now 5th industrial revolutions.
item.dc:creator: Tom White

item.title: Camden energy company Holtec International to pay $5 million to settle tax investigation
item.description: Holtec International has reached a settlement with the New Jersey Attorney General's Office ending the criminal investigation into Holtec providing fraudulent information to the state to earn tax breaks. Camden, will pay a $5 million fine and in exchange neither it nor executives will face criminal prosecution.
item.dc:creator: Kristin Hunt

item.title: Video shows fatal police shooting that killed Alexander Spencer inside Fairhill corner store
item.description: Authorities released surveillance video of the Philadelphia police shooting that killed Alexander Spencer after the man's mother and others questioned the use of lethal force. Police also identified the officer who shot and killed the 28-year-old as Raheem Hall inside a Fairhill corner store. The shooting is being investigated by police and the District Attorney's Office.
item.dc:creator: Chris Compendio

item.title: Philadelphia public schools hope to raise $40 million by 2028
item.description: At the School District of Philadelphia's first State of Public Education address, officials including Mayor Cherelle Parker and Superintendent Tony Watlington shared progress from the first year of the Accelerate Philly strategic plan and rallied for more money to fund it.
item.dc:creator: Kristin Hunt

item.title: Gov. Shapiro lays out sweeping plan to reform higher education in Pennsylvania
item.description: On Friday, Gov. Shapiro announced a plan to reform higher education in Pennsylvania. Under his proposal, a semester of school at a state university or community college would cost just $1,000 for many students. The plan also would unite Pennsylvania State System of Higher Education universities with the state‚Äôs 15 community colleges under a new governance system.
item.dc:creator: Peter Hall, Pennsylvania Capital-Star

item.title: Without clearly notifying public, Penn Museum buries remains of 19 Black Philadelphians held in its collection
item.description: The Penn Museum says it has buried 19 Black Philadelphians previously part of the Morton Cranial Collection ahead of a planned ceremony on Saturday. Anthropologists and organizers have expressed outrage at the museum's research on the individuals, and exclusion of descendant groups.
item.dc:creator: Kristin Hunt

item.title: Tolls to increase on New Jersey Turnpike, Garden State Parkway in March
item.description: Tolls on the New Jersey Turnpike and Garden State Parkway will increase by 3% March 1. Gov. Murphy is expected to approve the move, despite vetoing a plan to raise prices last year.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Nieto-Munoz, New Jersey Monitor

item.title: Effort to ban smoking in Atlantic City casinos moves forward as Senate advances bill
item.description: Atlantic City workers who support a ban on smoking inside casinos cheered and applauded lawmakers Monday afternoon after a state Senate committee finally advanced¬†a long-stalled measure¬†that would approve the ban. Gov. Phil Murphy has said he would sign the bill if it landed on his desk.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Nieto-Munoz, New Jersey Monitor

item.title: Camden's troubled Northgate One building to be converted into affordable housing tower
item.description: The Northgate One apartment tower in Camden, which sits at the foot of the Benjamin Franklin Bridge, has been acquired by Hudson Valley Property Group to be renovated and transformed into an affordable housing complex. The 21-story building was constructed in 1963. It fell into disrepair in recent decades and was plagued by maintenance and security issues.
item.dc:creator: Michael Tanenbaum

item.title: Shapiro among governors urging SCOTUS to rule in favor of medication abortion access
item.description: Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro is among 21 governors urging the U.S. Supreme Court to rule in favor of access to a drug used in medication abortions and managing miscarriages when it considers the issue next month. The Reproductive Freedom Alliance, of which Shapiro is a member, filed an amicus brief Tuesday in the appeal of a federal court decision that would restrict nationwide access to mifepristone, one of the drugs used in a two-step regimen used to end a pregnancy.
item.dc:creator: Peter Hall, Pennsylvania Capital-Star

item.title: Philadelphia gets $19.3 million for road safety projects from PennDOT, most directed to Roosevelt Boulevard work
item.description: PennDOT is allotting $19.3 million in funding for traffic safety projects in Philadelphia, with $12 million of that sum to be spent on improvements to Roosevelt Boulevard. The state grants are funded by revenue collected through fines issued to drivers caught speeding by the automated speed-monitoring cameras in Philadelphia.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Althouse

item.title: Temple to cover tuition for more Philadelphia students
item.description: A new Temple University financial aid program will cover tuition for qualifying Philadelphia students. The undergraduates must be enrolled full-time and have an adjusted family income of $65,000 or less.
item.dc:creator: Kristin Hunt

item.title: Plane crash in Chester County kills Octorara school board president
item.description: Sam Ganow, the school board president of the¬†Octorara Area School District, was killed in the small twin-engine plane crash near Coatesville on Thursday afternoon. Ganow, the pilot, was the only person on the aircraft. The plane left the Chester County Airport around 1:25 p.m., and the cause of the crash is under investigation by the NTSB.
item.dc:creator: Chris Compendio

item.title: Bucks County man accused of beheading father wanted Gov. Shapiro to 'join forces' against feds, prosecutors say
item.description: Justin Mohn, the Bucks County man who allegedly decapitated his father on Tuesday, allegedly wanted to speak with Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro to convince him to raise arms in rebellion against the federal government, prosecutors said Friday. Mohn, 32, allegedly had a 'clear mind' after his arrest at a National Guard base in Lebanon County on Tuesday night, District Attorney Jennifer Schorn said.
item.dc:creator: Michael Tanenbaum

item.title: Renovations planned for Marconi Plaza include the new bocce courts, fitness equipment and more trees
item.description: A plan for improvements to Marconi Plaza in South Philly includes new lighting, better crosswalks, more trees and new bocce courts. It is unclear if the Christopher Columbus statue will be affected.
item.dc:creator: Kristin Hunt

item.title: Police identify and charge man who allegedly shot at narcotics officer during search
item.description: Libao Zheng, 26, is accused of shooting an officer who was part of a narcotics unit serving a warrant. A bullet ricocheted off the officer's bulletproof vest and hit his hand. Charges against Zheng include attempted murder.
item.dc:creator: Chris Compendio
